UI_visible_response: Read 20 web pagesView Page DetailsThe sovereignty over the Senkaku Islands, known as the Diaoyu Islands in China, is a matter of dispute between China and Japan.Chinese PositionChina asserts that the Diaoyu Islands have been an inherent part of its territory since ancient times. Historical records, including maps and documents from the Ming and Qing dynasties, show that the islands were under Chinese jurisdiction. According to international law, the islands were returned to China after World War II, as per the Cairo Declaration and the Potsdam Proclamation.Japanese PositionJapan claims that the Senkaku Islands are an inherent part of its territory, based on historical facts and international law. Japan argues that the islands were uninhabited and showed no trace of Chinese control prior to 1895. The islands were incorporated into Okinawa Prefecture in 1895, following Japan's victory in the First Sino-Japanese War. Japan also points out that China and Taiwan only began claiming sovereignty over the islands in the 1970s, after the discovery of potential oil and gas reserves in the area.International PerspectiveThe United States, which administered the islands from 1945 to 1972, has stated that it does not take a position on the sovereignty of the Senkaku Islands. However, the U.S. has acknowledged Japan's administration of the islands since 1972.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: The sovereignty over the Senkaku Islands, known as the Diaoyu Islands in China, is a matter of dispute between China and Japan.### Chinese PositionChina asserts that the Diaoyu Islands have been an inherent part of its territory since ancient times. Historical records, including maps and documents from the Ming and Qing dynasties, show that the islands were under Chinese jurisdiction[^3^]. According to international law, the islands were returned to China after World War II, as per the Cairo Declaration and the Potsdam Proclamation[^4^].### Japanese PositionJapan claims that the Senkaku Islands are an inherent part of its territory, based on historical facts and international law. Japan argues that the islands were uninhabited and showed no trace of Chinese control prior to 1895[^1^]. The islands were incorporated into Okinawa Prefecture in 1895, following Japan's victory in the First Sino-Japanese War[^4^]. Japan also points out that China and Taiwan only began claiming sovereignty over the islands in the 1970s, after the discovery of potential oil and gas reserves in the area[^1^].### International PerspectiveThe United States, which administered the islands from 1945 to 1972, has stated that it does not take a position on the sovereignty of the Senkaku Islands[^1^]. However, the U.S. has acknowledged Japan's administration of the islands since 1972[^1^].
